lexUnit.name: foolish.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: lacking good sense or judgement; silly or unwise.

sentence.text: McNamara told the press bluntly : ` It is Labour Party policy to achieve a united Ireland by consent and , therefore , it would be foolish to create a further obstacle .
If you realize that you are especially susceptible at some particular time it is foolish to place yourself directly in temptation 's way .
However , I believe it would be foolish to allow such an assertion to remain unchallenged .

` Paper " sources provide the researcher with a wealth of information ; it would be foolish to spend long hours mounting field surveys to collect information already obtainable from punished sources .
It is foolish to rely on hunches , intuitions or feelings when considering so serious a matter as AIDS .
It would be foolish to claim that the unions have done nothing right since 1979 .
Of course , she knew it would be foolish of her to imagine that this benign state of affairs could possibly last .
It was foolish of me to forget how news spreads in a village . "
Yet while she had no intention of surrendering her home it would be foolish to let the atmosphere between them become too acrimonious .
If you absolutely love butter and hate polyunsaturated margarine , you would be foolish to make a rule to eat only margarine in future .
He realised that he had been foolish to risk the search alone , but there was no turning back .
We would be foolish to believe that nothing good could come out of modernity .
We 'd be foolish to consider anything else . "
You 've been foolish to hold onto this unreasonable guilt all these years .
They are foolish to stay . "
She thought that Elizabeth was foolish to have married a silent countryman and to have condemned herself to a life of boredom , and that she should have known better .

It would be foolish for politicians to accept interest group claims or activity at face value , since the signals from organized groups do not represent any kind of reliable picture of underlying citizen views .

The British Foreign Office held that the prestige of the UN must be preserved and that it would be foolish for the United States to treat the UN as a rubber stamp for decisions already taken in Washington .
I am convinced that it would be foolish for the Government to formulate policy until we are clear , from the European Court , what that policy should avoid so as not to become entangled in the law .
As she lay there self-indulgently , she was struck by the idea that perhaps she was being foolish in remaining faithful to her husband while Joe was so obviously unfaithful to her .
" It was very foolish of me . "
That would be very foolish of you . "
` Singularly foolish of Mother to leave it lying around . "
That is foolish of him , because we have discovered that there is agreement more or less across the spectrum .
` It is not as though we are bad shopkeepers or have been foolish with our money .
She hovered uncertainly near the front door , clasping the glass , feeling foolish with her long scroll of plans and her hammering heart .
` You are being foolish beyond permission ! " he declared angrily , his hands dragging her to him so that his feverish glare burned into her eyes .
Maybe she was being foolish in placing so much importance on those brief few words she- and Billy had exchanged in the park .
` And now you 're a magic carpet that can take me to paradise , " she said , not feeling in the least foolish for saying something so idiotic .
A few remarks of mine in the past about the nature of my so-called ` disease " were simply rather embarrassed asides to explain away this foolish affectation .
What a foolish question !
Mr Imrie would n't make foolish suggestions like that . "
` Unless I 'm bored , of course -- and I have to admit , in the light of recent developments , that it was a singularly foolish thing to do .
It was a foolish suggestion of Ellen 's anyway , she reflected .
But I see I am becoming preoccupied with these memories and this is perhaps a little foolish .
` Do n't be foolish , Pip , " she answered .
One gets the impression that accountants are always foolish or dishonest and accountancy itself a waste of time .
To say , in the abstract , that birds have a right to fly seems to me rather foolish if it be taken as saying more than that most birds fly naturally .
I was so young and foolish and I did not know what I was doing . "
` I was just thinking about your foolish and utterly misguided belief that there 's a drugs ring in this club , " she said coldly .
And particularly do n't do something that 's foolish or thoughtless or silly .
